isis.stitle: VT 365 Diesel Engine - 2004 Model Year - CRANKCASE, CRANKSHAFT and BEARINGS, CAMSHAFT and BUSHINGS - Cleaning, Inspection, and Testing - Crankcase Assembly

note.para: Clean the crankcase in a chemical bath or hot tank. This removes all carbonized material and mineral deposits in coolant passages.

item.para: If a hot tank is not available, do the following steps:

note.para: Thoroughly clean and inspect crankcase before and after reconditioning.

step1.para: Use nonmetallic stiff bristle brushes and scrapers to clean gasket material from machined surfaces of crankcase.
Clean cylinder bore with soap, water, and a nylon stiff bristle brush.
Clean lower crankcase in solvent.

warning.para: To prevent personal injury or death, wear safety glasses with side shields to protect eyes. Limit compressed air pressure to 207 kPa (30 psi).

step1.para: Dry with filtered compressed air.

figure.caption: Removal of oil gallery cup plugs

step1.para: To remove main oil gallery cup plug (in rear of crankcase), use a punch and hammer near edge of plug and strike with a hammer.
Remove plug from crankcase and discard.
Clean main galleries with an Oil Gallery Cleaning Brush .

note.para: Use Liquid Gasket (RTV) before installing main oil gallery core plugs.

step1.para: Coat edges of new oil gallery cup plugs with liquid gasket. Use an Oil Gallery Plug Driver and install new oil gallery cup plugs. The oil gallery plug driver installs the oil gallery cup plug to the correct depth. It should be flush with the crankcase surface to approximately 1.50 mm (0.060 in) below surface.

caution.para: To prevent engine damage, threads in the crankcase bolt holes must be clean and blown dry with filtered compressed air. Dirt or oil left in holes may cause binding and a false torque reading during assembly.

step1.para: Clean cylinder head bolt holes with a head bolt bottoming tap .

warning.para: To prevent personal injury or death, wear safety glasses with side shields to protect eyes. Limit compressed air pressure to 207 kPa (30 psi).

step1.para: Blow out chips with filtered compressed air.
After cleaning, inspect crankcase for cracks, scoring, roughness or wear at cylinder bores.

figure.caption: Flatness check for top surface of cylinder block

step1.para: Use a straightedge to check the cylinder block top surface of crankcase (firing deck) for flatness. Insert a feeler gauge between straightedge and crankcase head surface.

step2.para: Measure the whole deck surface. If the gap exceeds the specifications , the crankcase must be replaced.
Divide the deck surface into 150 mm x 150 mm areas and measure each square area. If the gap exceeds the specifications , the crankcase must be replaced.
Divide the deck surface into 25 mm x 25 mm areas and measure each square area. If the gap exceeds the specifications , the crankcase must be replaced.

caution.para: Do not resurface the crankcase. Surface defects beyond those listed above are not correctable.

step1.para: If cylinder walls have minor surface damage, but are otherwise within out-of-round specifications, it may be possible to remove damage by honing.
Use a cylinder bore gauge to check cylinder bore out-of-round conditions.

step2.para: Measure diameter of cylinder bore at top of piston ring travel. Be sure to measure at a right angle to the center line of crankshaft (dimension A). Record reading.
Measure each bore so gauge reading coincides with center line of crankshaft (dimension B). Record reading.
The difference between dimension A and dimension B is the out-of-round condition at the top of the cylinder bore.

step1.para: Repeat the same procedure at the bottom of ring travel to check for out-of-round condition.

caution.para: To prevent engine damage, if cylinder bores are deeply scored, out-of-round or exceeds specifications, all cylinders must be bored out to an oversize dimension.

step1.para: If cylinder bore is within specifications , standard size pistons and rings may be used.

item.para: If cylinder bore is suitable for use without reconditioning, deglaze the cylinder bore before assembling. See Cylinder deglazing in this section for further details.

note.para: Piston cooling tubes must be removed before deglazing cylinder bores.

step1.para: Use a Deglazing Hone (four-inch) to deglaze the cylinder bore. This silicone carbide-tipped nylon flexible brush quickly deglazes cylinder walls and produces a crosshatch pattern on the cylinder wall surface in a single operation. The brush contours itself to the cylinder wall and conditions wall surface without altering cylinder bore.
Spray cylinder and Deglazing Hone with penetrating fluid or equivalent. This spray contains colloidal graphite and works well.
Attach Deglazing Hone to a variable speed electric or air powered drill.

note.para: For a successful procedure 100 to 120 rpm is required.

step1.para: Deglaze cylinder wall for about 15 seconds. Stroke bore up and down at a rate of one complete up and down stroke per second.
Withdraw deglazing hone from cylinder bore while rotating. Wipe portion of cylinder wall and inspect cross hatch pattern.

note.para: The cross hatch pattern left by the abrasive tool should be approximately 45°.

item.para: If pattern is "flatter" than required, increase up and down stroke speed or slow down drill rotation as required.

step1.para: Continue deglazing cylinder bore for 10 to 15 seconds or 20 to 25 strokes.
Wipe cylinder bore clean and inspect bore for correct 45° cross hatch pattern.
After deglazing, thoroughly clean cylinder bores with soft bristle brush, soap and water.

warning.para: To prevent personal injury or death, wear safety glasses with side shields to protect eyes. Limit compressed air pressure to 207 kPa (30 psi).

step1.para: Dry with filtered compressed air.
Lubricate bores with clean engine oil
